"Uncut Gems" was a remarkable take on a crime story that managed to be interesting, emotional, and incredibly enjoyable. Although the setup, which lasted about 20 minutes, was rather confusing and had too much happening at once for a movie's beginning, it immediately picked up. This movie's direction and script blended together in an absolutely extraordinary way, that led to layers which were complex, but brilliantly written and shown. It was a film made up of multiple plotlines that were able to create one exceptional story, something that most movies are unable to do. The acting was out of this world, Adam Sandler giving a performance that even the best of actors would be unable to execute. This movie has anxiety-inducing scenes that build upon each other to put you in such suspense you'll want to shut the TV off, but your eyes are glued to the screen. When it comes to characters, the main one is outstandingly written, with the audience hating him so much, yet wanting him to succeed more than anything. However, the other characters are not very appealing, as we don't get to dig into their personalities much. Besides this and the beginning of the film, "Uncut Gems" managed to surprise me and engulf me in a journey unlike any other.

A thrilling, addictive, anxiety attack of a film made with a level of technical assurance and mastery that's rarely equalled - with Adam Sandler in a career redefining performance. The often overlapping dialogue is redolent of the increasingly confused and fractured state of the central character's psyche - maybe it's just my age, but you may well need the subtitles on to hear much of what's said. In many senses, it reminded me of Trainspotting - though not as good, and unlikely to be generation-defining in the way that film was. For me, its echoes of the Danny Boyle film were in the way it seems to be structured to echo the addict's trip  - in Trainspotting it's the high of the chemically addicted, here it's gambling. It's also no coincidence that this takes place over Passover, and Sandler's character's Jewishness is often referenced. As if to ram the point home, one part of the Passover rituals we see is the recitation of the plagues on Egypt; the suggestion seems to be that Ratner (Sandler) is a man experiencing his own 12 plagues, a man with nothing at his centre having his glittering surface stripped away to reveal his empty core (I also wondered if he was an impure but otherwise Job-like figure, but that seems even more of a stretch). If we take the Passover reading of the film, the question that drives the narrative is if Ratner has daubed blood on the doorframe and fulfilled all ritual righteousness. It's a question only answered in the film's final moments. However you read it, you'll need something to decompress with afterwards.

The entire film can be summed up this way: I did not see that coming, but I should have. Many might call that a flaw. Others recognize it as genius. I'm in the latter category.
